title: (CS11002) Programming Paradigms for Computing Spring ’26
text:
Faculty

Prof. Partha Pratim Chakrabarti (ppchak@cse.iitkgp.ac.in)
Prof. Sudeshna Sarkar (sudeshna@cse.iitkgp.ac.in)



Teaching Assistants

Ayan Maity (ayanmaity201@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in)
Prasanna Paithankar (paithankarprasanna@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in)
Niranjana Reddy B S (niranjan20@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in)
Deepraj Das (deeprajdas@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in)
Raj Pajesh Parikh (rajparikh@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in)



Grading Policy

Assignments + Tutorials + Attendance: 15%
Class tests: 15%
Mid-semester: 25%
End-semester: 45%



Logistics

Class timings: Monday, Wednesday, Friday - 11:00 AM to 11:50 AM
Venue: NR 422, Nalanda Classroom Complex



Syllabus








Module
Title/Topic Area
Key Contents




1
Introduction
Basics of machine models and data models; data structures and algorithms; models of computation; computational modeling of real-world phenomena; simulations and learning


2
Problem Solving & Algorithms
Algorithms: termination & correctness; algorithm-to-program process; problem specification; decomposition and refinement; structured programming; data & control abstractions


3
Functional Paradigm
Function abstractions; designing functions as abstractions; higher-order functions; recursion and tree recursion


4
Abstractions with Data
Data abstraction; sequences; mutable data structures


5
Algorithmic Complexity
Time & space complexity; efficiency issues; searching & sorting algorithm examples


6
Object-Oriented Paradigm
Classes & objects; object abstraction; inheritance; recursive objects (linked lists, trees); graph data model


7
Data Representation & Visualization
Working with experimental and structured data


8
Numerical Computation
Simulations, interpolation, optimization; solving systems of equations; accuracy, convergence, efficiency considerations


9
Machine Learning Paradigm
Intro to ML; linear classification and regression


10
Logic Programming Paradigm
Declarative logic programs; goal & constraint satisfaction; backtracking; unification


11
Advanced Computing Paradigms
Parallel computing; quantum computing

title: Assignments
text:
Required Readings

 Computational Resource Offerings by IIT Kharagpur


 PC Setup Instructions

title: PC Setup
text:
I will lay down a non-opinionated guide to set up a programming environment on your personal computer which will be useful for this course and overall academic/non-academic programming tasks. Non-opinionated because you can and should experiment with various technologies to form your own personality.






Important



The required reading is highlighted.



Operating System
From the plethora of operating systems available, KGPians are mostly seen using (ranked by prevalence):

Windows (dowload through CIC 10.3.100.212 while connected to the campus network)
Ubuntu https://ubuntu.com/desktop
macOS
Fedora/Arch/Mint/Debian/Pop!_OS

Personal opinion: Windows is nice even for programming and doesn’t deserve the dislike it gets
This setup would be curated for Debian based systems (Ubuntu, Mint, Pop!_OS etc.) and Windows. Other Linux distributions should be similar to Ubuntu except the package manager commands (like Ubuntu uses apt, while Fedora uses dnf etc.)
Learn to use your package manager.


GitHub Account
Create a GitHub account. That’s it.


GitHub Student Developer Pack
Get https://education.github.com/pack


Git
https://git-scm.com/
Read https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2 thoroughly, its an essential tool and should be mastered in 1st year. These are building blocks which will be implicitly used in ALL your work. So give it a serious reading.


Code Editor/IDE
Use Visual Studio Code. The first things should be to link with your student activated GitHub account and install the Copilot, C/C++ and Python extensions (which are not languages but helper tools).


Programming Languages
These are the essential programming languages you should have installed and configured in your system. Follow the links to install and configure them properly in VS Code.

C/C++

Windows: mingw
Ubuntu: gcc

Python: Setup uv instead of direct Python and pip installation.
LaTeX: Setup LaTeX to write assignments/thesis/papers.

Other languages may be installed as per your requirement.


Other Required Packages (Linux)
Use your package manager to install the following essential packages:
ssh, curl, wget, make, nano, gdb
sudo apt update
sudo apt install curl wget make nano gdb openssh-client openssh-server openssl


Terminal (Linux)
I use Zsh with Oh My Zsh framework. Theme: robbyrussell Plugins: git, zsh-syntax-highlighting, zsh-autosuggestions Installation guide: https://ohmyz.sh
You can use any terminal like bash, fish, etc.


Terminal Tools (Linux)
tmux - To handle multiple terminal sessions bat - A better cat command with syntax highlighting fd - A better find command

title: Computational Resource Offerings by IIT Kharagpur
text:
Diving straight to the point:

Departmental Level
Each department has some resources, I will stick to CSE here.
 The official CSE resource compilation link
You can use the Software Lab machines for personal academic work (during non-lab hours till around 2 AM).
To get access to CPU and GPU clusters, fill out this form: https://cse.iitkgp.ac.in/archives/Server_Access_Form.pdf and submit it to the Software Lab Office, CSE Department.


Institute Level

Computer and Informatics Centre (CIC)
Website: https://cic.iitkgp.ac.in/
Want to fix your broken LAN socket? Contact CIC. Want your institute fest/event/society/conference/laboratory to have a website? Contact CIC. Want FREE Windows and MS Office licenses? Check the CIC website (PC should be on campus network).


ParamShakti Supercomputer
IIT Kharagpur very proudly hosts the 1.3 Peta Flop ParamShakti supercomputer, one of the fastest in India. The information can be found at its dedicated page: https://hpc.iitkgp.ac.in/.
Your project supervisor will inform you if you need access to this. (One of the coolest thing on campus according to me. Find and visit it sometime!)
